results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s.

This animated film, titled ‘Storm at the 20th’, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’
00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street
00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’
00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’
00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight
00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck
00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle
00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance
00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers
00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries
00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette
00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course
00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush
00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes
00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmão Film Collection]
results.material_description:
30 x reels 8mm film
Super 8mm and regular 8mm film collection, anotated list of content provided by donor see documents references window.
results.brief_description:
Kirsty Sword Gusmao AO is and Australian-East Timorese activist who served as the First Lady of East Timor from 2002 until 2007. She was married to Xanana Gusmao, Prime Minister and former President of Timor-Leste, now residing in Coburg, Melbourne. A collection of 8mm home movies including:
Sword family life, including holidays in the 1970s
Fictional student films from Eaglehawk Primary, north of Bendigo
Melbourne scenes inlcuding Tullamarine Airport
School camp
Bendigo Show
Hanging Rock excursion
Moonee Ponds
Indonesia - Denpasar
Fellowship trip to the USA

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Titled Walking to School.
This could possibly be an Eaglehawk Primary School Production.

This narrative film follows the eventful journey of a young school boy as he walks to school along a country road. On the way he is joined by school friends and we see their encounters with a variety of native Australian Wildlife. They see lace monitor tracks and follow them to where the monitor is scaling a tree. They also find a possum and an echidna. The film shows various closeups of the animals and the children’s faces as they squint and shield their eyes from the sun.

The children cross a wooden bridge where they meet an old man carrying a swag and a billy. The man gathers the children around him and reads a story to them called “The Bear”. The film then shows us the story as it is being told. It is a tale of a young girl who is very poor, very dirty and very sad. One day she finds a toy koala which brings her great joy. Excitedly she tries to show her Koala to other school children who are playing games in the school yard. They ridicule her and throw sticks at her. She runs away and falls on the grass where she drifts off to sleep. She dreams that she is rescued by a fairy Godmother who transforms her into a very clean girl in a beautiful dress! During this sequence we see good examples of Super 8 “special effects” as the fairy works her magic on the other children, transforming them into characters in fancy dress. We see these children playing circle games and closeups of their faces. Eventually the poor girl wakes up to find a kind school boy standing over her. He helps her to her feet, takes her hand and leads her to join his other friends. Together the group skip happily all the way to school along a country road.

This film shows good examples of children’s fashion, games and faces. We also see footage of houses and streets of the time.

Selected Highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 Title card ‘Walking to School’
00:00:30:00 Goanna climbing tree
00:02:23:00 Echidna
00:03:45:00 Kids story time reading from ‘The Bear’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a slice of life from a working dairy farm in central Gippsland, Victoria.

We see cows being milked, the milk cans being loaded onto trucks and in to the trays of utility cars. The milk is transported by road to the Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Company.

There are scenes of hay bales being driven around the paddocks in the back of a ute. The hay is divided in to sections and fed to the cattle. We see de-horned Jersey and Friesian cows and bulls eating the hay and children riding a WX 572 tractor.

There is footage of a newly born calf being licked clean by its mother and we see the calf’s first attempt to stand and take its first steps.

The film also shows a family visit to the Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point.

Selected sequence list (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:54:00 The Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Co LTD sign
00:02:12:00 Title card ‘A Calf is Born’
00:03:55:00 Dad and kids riding a tractor
00:04:00:00 Title card ‘Wattle Time’
00:04:38:00 Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 37]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows some wonderful car racing in Victoria and South Australia in 1953 and 1955. Includes the Templestowe and Rob Roy hill climbs, races at Altona and Baxter Park, and the Grand Prix at Port Wakefield.

While some footage is overexposed there are good scenes of the cars and spectators. Drivers shown include Jack Brabham, Reg Hunt, Kevin Neal and Doug Whiteford. Brabham is shown winning the 1955 Australian Grand Prix.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list

00:00:10 ‘Why the hurry fellows’ title card

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the wedding of the filmmaker’s daughter, Bettye Rankine to Robert (Bob) Wootton, both of whom would feature in Kenneth’s films. Of particular note are the opening sequences of the reel which show Kenneth’s interest in devising creative and clever titles. Kenneth frames shots of the soon to be bride and groom separately against a tree blowing in the breeze on a sunny day, as singles followed by ‘Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton in Our Wedding’ as the main title. Kenneth also uses his artistic sub-titles to separate sequences in the reel as well as his lingering shots of flowers (a device which he used regularly throughout his films). Highlights of the reel include the 1940s style of wedding and the wedding fashions of the era. Scenes at the wedding reception show some of the customs of day such as drinking an obligatory glass of sherry (usually upon arrival) and hosting the reception in the family home. Footage also includes the couple enjoying life with their first child some time later. The wedding segment ends with the couple shot in the same frame, now together and married as compared to the single shots of the opening title sequences.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:30:00 title cards, ‘Bettye Rankine and Robert Rankine in’ followed by, ‘Our Wedding’ which follow a preliminary sequence of the bride and groom shot individually.

00:00:34:00 scenes showing the preparation for the wedding reflects the more simple style of weddings of the era (late 1940s from the appearance of the car models). Although the wedding dress is of a lustrous satin fabric with a long train, it is a simple design compared to the prevailing current styles and the bride and groom are attended by only one attendant each.

00:01:28:00 shot of the full train of the wedding dress.

00:02:00:00 lovely look at Kenneth and Bettye on way to the car framed in the Rankine family driveway and garden.

00:02:16:00 scene showing the family were in a position to hire a car and chauffeur for the occasion.

00:02:28:00 Bettye Rankine in her wedding veil framed in the car window.

00:03:58:00 scenes at the church include a closeup of the bridal bouquets.

00:04:06:00 we see Mrs Rankine for the first time in a shot with Bettye and Kenneth outside the church.

00:04:55:00 the bridal couple arrive at their table at what seems to be a private home rather than a reception venue.

00:04:59:00 framed shot of guests drinking sherry at the reception.

00:05:20:00 Kenneth shows the bridal party and guests laughing and relaxed and the happy groom kissing the bride.

00:05:45:00 reception scenes give us a glimpse into the prevailing celebratory fashions and customs of the day - suits and hats and the occasional fur.

00:06:56:00 the wedding sequence ends with a formal title card ‘The End’ after we see the couple shot in the same frame, now together as compared to the single shots of the opening title.

00:07:05:00 title ‘And Now Kenneth Robert as Blue Eyes’ begins a sequence about the Wootton’s first child. Kenneth sets up a beginning sequence where we see Bettye and Bob and Mrs Rankine gazing at above at the sky looking (as we realise) for the stork to deliver the baby.

00:07:30:00 Kenneth Robert has arrived and there are lots of shots of him as a very happy baby in the sunny family garden.

00:08:04:00 Kenneth devises some scenes where Bob Wootton is polishing a car that suddenly turns in to a larger car that he then shows off to Mrs Rankine and Bettye. Cars feature in Kenneth’s films including a scene here where he and Bob reverse the wide cars down the narrow driveway which was typical of the house style at the time.

00:12:18:00 a title for the baby at one year old showing height, chest, weight and number of teeth. We immediately see footage of what is likely to be the baby christening at what appears to be a country church.

00:13:15:00 showing us the baby now crawling on a rug in the family garden.

00:14:28:00 the baby is sitting playing with a ‘Kool Mints’ tin, playing with water, clapping with his mother and being tickled; the baby being fed what appears to be sugar on a plastic spoon gripped in his teeth to cover his nose, sitting on his stroller and learning to walk between his parents;

00:17:10:00 the baby walks independently and soon after is tottering around the garden.

00:17:46:00 with another flower to separate scenes, we see the baby sliding around the garden on a spade being held by his father, running with a pull-along toy, riding around on a broom; playing with a balloon that bursts, looking quite confident with the camera, playing with a spinning top.

00:19:37:00 title card for the baby at two which includes height and weight followed by a brief shot of the toddler ending with a final flower.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows views across the Melbourne CBD rooftops and steeples, a selection of ‘flowering gums’, a visit to the Botanical Gardens, the arrival of ‘flat tops’ aircraft carrier ships. Kenneth then shows off the neon signs of Melbourne at night.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:20:00 title ‘Melbourne’.

00:00:26:00 views from what appears to be the top of the Royal Melbourne Children’s Hospital in North Melbourne with a note, ‘From Here 178 Feet’ beginning with a view down Elizabeth St toward the CBD.

00:01:06:00 an eastern view, where the Dandenong Ranges can be seen in the distance.

00:01:28:00 to 00:01:37:00 views over Melbourne University toward Queen’s College and the Royal Exhibition Building.

00:01:58:00 a horse and cart enter a city intersection at same time as a tram and cars.

00:02:47:00 Melbourne Technical College rotunda.

00:03:05:00 the Pelaco sign in Richmond (a Heritage Victoria listed landmark). Pelaco is a Melbourne based shirt manufacturing business.

00:30:00:00 Elizabeth St with Flinders St Station in view ends the footage of the rooftops of Melbourne.

00:04:30:00 title card ‘Flowering Gums’ followed by a selection of trees and shrubs in flower.

00:06:52:00 title card ‘Botanical Gardens’ begins a look at people enjoying the gardens. Footage includes examples of fox furs being worn by some women strolling in the gardens.

00:09:28:00 a quick look at what appears to be Captain Cook’s cottage.

00:09:35:00 title card ‘V.A.C.S On Location’ begins a sequence of what appears to be a film being made.

00:10:45:00 title card ‘The Flat Tops Arrive’ footage of large ships (aircraft carriers) and tugboats in the bay viewed by watchers on a small pier near, presumably, Port Melbourne.

00:12:42:00 a plane goes overhead. The sequence ends at at night on the beach. with people overlooking the bay toward the horizon.

00:15:11:00 title ‘Bright Lights’, a sequence at night showing neon signs around Melbourne.

00:16:03:00 the face of Luna Park in St Kilda.

00:16:24:00 Fostor’s Lager advertising sign.

00:16:35:00 Berger Paints (British Paints) advertising sign.

00:16:40:00 to 00:16:55:00 Swallows and Ariells ‘Follow the Swallow’ sequenced advertisement for Uneeda Biscuits, Plum Pudding and Biscuits Cakes Ice cream.

00:16:58:00 Sunshine Milk advertising sign.

00:17:15:00 Ball and Welch department store sign on Flinders St with the T&G Building sign in the background.

00:17:23:00 shows a longer sequence advertisement for Sennets ice cream featuring a bear eating an ice cream.

00:18:00:00 possibly the top dome of the Royal Exhibition Building lit up.

00:18:25:00 ‘Visit the Zoo’ advertising flashes up on screen.

00:19:05:00 advertisement ‘Mascot Underwear for Men and Boys’ featuring a ram and lamb on his back.

00:19:09:00 ‘Dunlop Tyres’ advertising sign.

00:19:33:00 footage ends with blurred city lights and traffic lights turning to red.

00:09:28:00 a quick look at what appears to be Captain Cook’s cottage.

00:09:35:00 title card ‘V.A.C.S On Location’ begins a sequence of what appears to be a film being made.

00:10:45:00 title card ‘The Flat Tops Arrive’ footage of large ships (aircraft carriers) and tugboats in the bay viewed by watchers on a small pier near, presumably, Port Melbourne.

00:12:42:00 a plane goes overhead. The sequence ends at at night on the beach. with people overlooking the bay toward the horizon.

00:15:11:00 title ‘Bright Lights’, a sequence at night showing neon signs around Melbourne.

00:16:03:00 the face of Luna Park in St Kilda.

00:16:24:00 Fostor’s Lager advertising sign.

00:16:35:00 Berger Paints (British Paints) advertising sign.

00:16:40:00 to 00:16:55:00 Swallows and Ariells ‘Follow the Swallow’ sequenced advertisement for Uneeda Biscuits, Plum Pudding and Biscuits Cakes Ice cream.

00:16:58:00 Sunshine Milk advertising sign.

00:17:15:00 Ball and Welch department store sign on Flinders St with the T&G Building sign in the background.

00:17:23:00 shows a longer sequence advertisement for Sennets ice cream featuring a bear eating an ice cream.

00:18:00:00 possibly the top dome of the Royal Exhibition Building lit up.

00:18:25:00 ‘Visit the Zoo’ advertising flashes up on screen.

00:19:05:00 advertisement ‘Mascot Underwear for Men and Boys’ featuring a ram and lamb on his back.

00:19:09:00 ‘Dunlop Tyres’ advertising sign.

00:19:33:00 footage ends with blurred city lights and traffic lights turning to red.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this home movie, we see footage of Wirth’s Circus, including acrobats, trained elephants and horses, and trapeze artists, followed by footage of Luna Park in Melbourne.

The film then travels to Adelaide, meeting the arrival of ‘The Overland’ train from Melbourne, followed by visits to Torrens Lake, Koala Bear Park and Torrens Gorge.

The final section of the film shows the ANZAC March in Melbourne (1938) and a family road trip to Sassafras in the Dandenongs.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.
